Context:
The text provides information about the Cook Apprenticeship program offered by George Brown College under the Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD). The program schedule operates from Monday to Friday, with some classes starting as early as 7 a.m. and ending as late as 10 p.m. Students are required to complete a 14-week industry work-integrated learning program, where they can pursue both employer-identified opportunities and self-directed ones. Career options for graduates include numerous restaurants, hotels, clubs, resorts, spas, catering companies in Toronto and internationally. Graduates may be eligible for direct entry into several George Brown College programs, including Culinary Arts – Italian, Food and Nutrition Management (additional Accounting course required), Advanced French Patisserie, and the third year of Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) and Honours Bachelor of Food Studies programs. Additional courses may be required for graduates to enter these programs. The first semester required courses include HOSF1145 - Sanitation, HOST1068 - Smart Serve, HOSF1184 - Café Production, HOSF1185 - Fundamentals of Butchery, HOSF1255 - Nutrition Fundamentals from a Culinary Perspective, and HOSF1296 - Beverage and Service Fundamentals.

No emails or phone numbers were provided in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Culinary Management Program H100 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides a list of courses offered in different semesters for a program in the college, possibly related to Culinary Arts or Hospitality Management. Here's an extraction of factual information from the text:

Semester 1:
- F1296: Beverage and Service Fundamentals
- HOSF1202: Culinary Foundations
- HOSF1203: Culinary Essentials
- HOSF1029: Theory of Food I
- HOSF1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)
- COMM2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- MATH1200: Culinary Math Essentials
- GSCI1035: Science of Sustainability

Semester 2:
- HOSF1287: WHMIS
- HOSF1002: Baking and Pastry for Cooks
- HOSF1166: Foods of the World
- HOSF1297: The Sustainable Chef
- HOSF1204: Culinary Principles
- HOSF1205: Culinary Concepts
- HOSF1031: Theory of Food II
- HOST1005: Food, Beverage and Labour Cost Control (hybrid)
- Career Preparation

Semester 3 – Stream 1:
- HOSF2064: Human Resources (online)
- HOSF2077: Marketing (online)
- HOSF2076: Industry Mentor/Externship
- GNED: General Education Elective (online)

Semester 4 – Stream 2:
- HOSF2047: Food for Special Events and Catering
- HOSF2062: Marriage of Food and Wine
- HOSF2048: Essential Flavours of the Modern Kitchen
- HOSF2081: Hospitality Leadership and Communication
- HOSF2082: Business Entrepreneurship/Menu Management
- GNED: General Education Elective

Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000. COMM 1000 is not a required course for graduation and students will be charged for this extra course. For more information, please visit Assessment Centre.

General Education Electives are also part of the program.

Context:
The text describes the roles and responsibilities of individuals in food service programs offered by the college. These include applying food science techniques to food preparation, ensuring a safe kitchen environment, creating menus reflecting nutrition knowledge, managing foodservice operations with business principles, and using technology for food production. Context:
George Brown College has sensitivity towards religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods for products used in production and consumption, as they comply with all provincial and federal regulations.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System. For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page. Financial and fees-related inquiries can be directed to the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or the Financial Aid web page. For Culinary Management inquiries, contact CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca.

International students can contact recruitment representatives specialized by country of origin through booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page. George Brown College offers Discovery Days to learn about various areas of interest and visit facilities. Programs related to Culinary Management include H116 (Integrated Learning), H134 (Culinary Skills), and H113 (Baking and Pastry Arts Management).

Contact information:
- Domestic student admissions: admissions@georgebrown.ca, George Brown College website
- Financial Aid: FinAid@georgebrown.ca, George Brown College Financial Aid web page
- Culinary Management inquiries: CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca
- Contact Centre: 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559), 1-800-265-2002

Testimonial from an international student, Sasekea, from Jamaica. She expressed her gratitude towards George Brown College for providing exposure to various North American and South Asian cuisines and the support from chefs and staff at the International Centre. Now, she works as an apprentice cook at the Delta Hotel.

Context: Sasekea Shakespeare is a graduate of George Brown College with an Ontario College Diploma. The college offers campus tours and info sessions for those interested in applying.
